questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 45-year-old female patient who experiences bleeding after sexual intercourse, and upon per vaginal examination, a lesion is observed that bleeds when touched?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cervical polyp

Explanation:

  • In this case, the patient presents with post-coital bleeding, and a per vaginal examination reveals a vascular lesion that bleeds easily when touched, which is characteristic of a cervical polyp. These are benign growths that arise from the mucous membrane of the cervical canal and are commonly associated with post-coital or irregular bleeding.

Cervical Polyp

  • A benign growth in the cervical canal, often found in women aged 30-50, though they can occur at any stage.

Â 

  • Origin: Typically from the endocervical canal, occasionally the ectocervix.
  • Size and Shape: Small (few millimeters to 2 cm), finger-like or stalked.
  • Color: Red/purplish (vascular) or pale (fibrous).

Symptoms:

  • Postcoital bleeding
  • Intermenstrual bleeding
  • Vaginal discharge

Diagnosis:

  • Colposcopy
  • Pap smear/Biopsy: To rule out malignancy.

Management:

  • Polypectomy:
  • Histopathology: To confirm benign nature.

Incorrect Options:

Hemorrhagic cysts (Option A) typically occur within or on the surface of the ovary. They are not associated with post-coital bleeding or lesions on the cervix.

Cervical cancer (Option C) can cause irregular bleeding, including post-coital bleeding, but the lesion typically does not bleed on light touch and may require significant friction or manipulation to exhibit bleeding.

Cervical fibroids (Option D) are rare and more likely to present with post-coital pain or symptoms related to their size, such as interference with urination, rather than easy bleeding upon touch.

questions.text: What is the best diagnostic test for evaluating endometrial pathology?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hysteroscopy-guided endometrial biopsy

Explanation:

  • Hysteroscopy-guided endometrial biopsy allows direct visualization of the uterine cavity and targeted sampling of suspicious areas, making it the gold standard for diagnosing focal and diffuse endometrial lesions.
  • It improves diagnostic accuracy, especially for polyps, submucosal fibroids, and localized carcinoma.
  • Direct visualization prevents sampling errors common in blind methods like D&C or Pipelle.
  • Allows simultaneous diagnosis and treatment (e.g., polyp removal).
  • Particularly useful in abnormal uterine bleeding, postmenopausal bleeding, and inconclusive imaging results.

Incorrect Options:

Pipelle endometrial biopsy (Option A): Minimally invasive and good for detecting diffuse pathology (e.g., endometrial carcinoma), but can miss focal lesions.

Dilatation and curettage (D&C) (Option C): Blind procedure with lower sensitivity for focal lesions; now used mainly for incomplete abortion or therapeutic purposes.

Transvaginal sonography (Option D): Excellent screening tool to measure endometrial thickness but cannot confirm histology.
